description.text: The α field describes the machine environment and contains just one entry.
The β field provides details of processing characteristics and constraints and may contain no entry at all, a single entry, or multiple entries.
The γ field describes the objective to be minimized and often contains a single entry.

qualifiers.value: Providing versions of the simulation model and with characteristics to distinguish them.

"Designation of the exchange format of the model. E.G.: FMI 1.0, Co-Simulation, Platform / Source - Code. FMI 2.0.2, Model Exchange, Source - Code. S-function, Version 2, 64bit, mex - Format / or C-Code. Modelica 3, encoded. VHDL
Provision of a version of the simulation model with information to distinguish the versions. The versions are primarily intended for bug fixes without content changes.
List of modeling approaches used for the model.
Linear model; Nonlinear model; Data-driven model; Lumped element model; Fixed causality model; Acausal model
List of basic physical characteristics which are represented by the model.
Logic and timing behaviour; Geometry; Kinematics; Dynamics; Distribution networks; Network communication; Visualization

description.text: The α field describes the machine environment and contains just one entry.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

description.text: The β field provides details of processing characteristics and constraints and may contain no entry at all, a single entry, or multiple entries.

definition.text: The β field provides details of processing characteristics and constraints and may contain no entry at all, a single entry, or multiple entries.

description.text: The case of a single machine is the simplest of all possible machine environments and is a special case of all other more complicated machine environments.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: The case of a single machine is the simplest of all possible machine environments and is a special case of all other more complicated machine environments.

description.text: There are m identical machines in parallel. Job j requires a single operation and may be processed on any one of the m machines or on any one that belongs to a given subset.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: There are m identical machines in parallel. Job j requires a single operation and may be processed on any one of the m machines or on any one that belongs to a given subset.

description.text: There are m machines in parallel with different speeds.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: There are m machines in parallel with different speeds.

description.text: There are m different machines in parallel, where the processing speed dedends on the job.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: <own definition>

definition.text: There are m different machines in parallel, where the processing speed dedends on the job.

description.text: There are m machines in series. Each job has to be processed on each one of the m machines. All jobs have to follow the same route, i.e., they have to be processed first on machine 1, then on machine 2, and so on. After completion on one machine a job joins the queue at the next machine. Usually, all queues are assumed to operate under the First In First Out (FIFO) discipline, that is, a job cannot “pass” another while waiting in a queue.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: There are m machines in series. Each job has to be processed on each one of the m machines. All jobs have to follow the same route, i.e., they have to be processed first on machine 1, then on machine 2, and so on. After completion on one machine a job joins the queue at the next machine. Usually, all queues are assumed to operate under the First In First Out (FIFO) discipline, that is, a job cannot “pass” another while waiting in a queue.

description.text: A flexible flow shop is a generalization of the flow shop and the parallel machine environments. Instead of m machines in series there are c stages in series with at each stage a number of identical machines in parallel. Each job has to be processed first at stage 1, then at stage 2, and so on. A stage functions as a bank of parallel machines; at each stage, job j requires processing on only one machine and any machine can do. The queues between the various stages may or may not operate according to the First Come First Served (FCFS) discipline.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: A flexible flow shop is a generalization of the flow shop and the parallel machine environments. Instead of m machines in series there are c stages in series with at each stage a number of identical machines in parallel. Each job has to be processed first at stage 1, then at stage 2, and so on. A stage functions as a bank of parallel machines; at each stage, job j requires processing on only one machine and any machine can do. The queues between the various stages may or may not operate according to the First Come First Served (FCFS) discipline.

description.text: In a job shop with m machines each job has its own predetermined route to follow.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: In a job shop with m machines each job has its own predetermined route to follow.

description.text: A flexible job shop is a generalization of the job shop and the parallel machine environments. Instead of m machines in series there are c work centers with at each work center a number of identical machines in parallel. Each job has its own route to follow through the shop; job j requires processing at each work center on only one machine and any machine can do.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: A flexible job shop is a generalization of the job shop and the parallel machine environments. Instead of m machines in series there are c work centers with at each work center a number of identical machines in parallel. Each job has its own route to follow through the shop; job j requires processing at each work center on only one machine and any machine can do.

description.text: There are m machines. Each job has to be processed again on each one of the m machines. However, some of these processing times may be zero. There are no restrictions with regard to the routing of each job through the machine environment. The scheduler is allowed to determine a route for each job and different jobs may have different routes.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: There are m machines. Each job has to be processed again on each one of the m machines. However, some of these processing times may be zero. There are no restrictions with regard to the routing of each job through the machine environment. The scheduler is allowed to determine a route for each job and different jobs may have different routes.

description.text: If this symbol appears in the β field, then job j cannot start its processing before its release date rj. If rj does not appear in the β field, the processing of job j may start at any time.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: If this symbol appears in the β field, then job j cannot start its processing before its release date rj. If rj does not appear in the β field, the processing of job j may start at any time.

description.text: The sij represents the sequence dependent setup time that is incurred between the processing of jobs i and j.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: The sij represents the sequence dependent setup time that is incurred between the processing of jobs i and j.

description.text: Preemptions imply that it is not necessary to keep a job on a machine, once started, until its completion. The scheduler is allowed to interrupt the processing of a job (preempt) at any point in time and put a different job on the machine instead.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: Preemptions imply that it is not necessary to keep a job on a machine, once started, until its completion. The scheduler is allowed to interrupt the processing of a job (preempt) at any point in time and put a different job on the machine instead.

description.text: Recirculation may occur in a job shop or flexible job shop when a job may visit a machine or work center more than once.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: Recirculation may occur in a job shop or flexible job shop when a job may visit a machine or work center more than once.

description.text: Precedence constraints may appear in a single machine or in a parallel machine environment, requiring that one or more jobs may have to be completed before another job is allowed to start ist processing.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: Precedence constraints may appear in a single machine or in a parallel machine environment, requiring that one or more jobs may have to be completed before another job is allowed to start ist processing.

description.text: The n jobs belong in this case to F different job families. Jobs from the same family may have different processing times, but they can be processed on a machine one after another without requiring any setup in between.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: The n jobs belong in this case to F different job families. Jobs from the same family may have different processing times, but they can be processed on a machine one after another without requiring any setup in between.

description.text: A machine may be able to process a number of jobs, say b, simultaneously; that is, it can process a batch of up to b jobs at the same time. The processing times of the jobs in a batch may not be all the same and the entire batch is finished only when the last job of the batch has been completed, implying that the completion time of the entire batch is determined by the job with the longest processing time.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: A machine may be able to process a number of jobs, say b, simultaneously; that is, it can process a batch of up to b jobs at the same time. The processing times of the jobs in a batch may not be all the same and the entire batch is finished only when the last job of the batch has been completed, implying that the completion time of the entire batch is determined by the job with the longest processing time.

description.text: Machine breakdowns imply that a machine may not be continuously available.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: Machine breakdowns imply that a machine may not be continuously available.

description.text: When the Mj is present, not all m machines are capable of processing job j. Set Mj denotes the set of machines that can process job j.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: When the Mj is present, not all m machines are capable of processing job j. Set Mj denotes the set of machines that can process job j.

description.text: A constraint that may appear in the flow shop environment is that the queues in front of each machine operate according to the First In First Out (FIFO) discipline. This implies that the order (or permutation) in which the jobs go through the first machine is maintained throughout the system.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: A constraint that may appear in the flow shop environment is that the queues in front of each machine operate according to the First In First Out (FIFO) discipline. This implies that the order (or permutation) in which the jobs go through the first machine is maintained throughout the system.

description.text: Blocking implies that the completed job has to remain on the upstream machine preventing (i.e., blocking) that machine from working on the next job.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: Blocking implies that the completed job has to remain on the upstream machine preventing (i.e., blocking) that machine from working on the next job.

description.text: Jobs are not allowed to wait between two successive machines. This implies that the starting time of a job at the first machine has to be delayed to ensure that the job can go through the flow shop without having to wait for any machine.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: Jobs are not allowed to wait between two successive machines. This implies that the starting time of a job at the first machine has to be delayed to ensure that the job can go through the flow shop without having to wait for any machine.

description.text: The makespan, defined as max(C1, . . . , Cn), is equivalent to the completion time of the last job to leave the system. A minimum makespan usually implies a good utilization of the machine(s).

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: The makespan, defined as max(C1, . . . , Cn), is equivalent to the completion time of the last job to leave the system. A minimum makespan usually implies a good utilization of the machine(s).

description.text: Total completion time of all jobs

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: <own definition>

definition.text: Total completion time of all jobs

description.text: The total weighted completion times of the n jobs gives an indication of the total holding or inventory costs incurred by the schedule.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: The total weighted completion times of the n jobs gives an indication of the total holding or inventory costs incurred by the schedule.

description.text: Maximal earliness of jobs. Considers only derivations from the due date that are too early: max(0;(dj-Cj)

description.text: The maximum lateness, Lmax, is defined as max(L1, . . . , Ln). It measures the worst violation of the due dates.

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: Scheduling - Theory, Algorithms, and Systems, 2016, ISBN: 978-3-319-26578-0

definition.text: The maximum lateness, Lmax, is defined as max(L1, . . . , Ln). It measures the worst violation of the due dates.

description.text: Total lateness of jobs. Considers all derivation of the due date: Cj-dj

dataSpecificationContent.sourceOfDefinition: <own definition>

definition.text: Total lateness of jobs. Considers all derivation of the due date: Cj-dj

description.text: Weighted total lateness of jobs. Considers all derivation of the due date: w(Cj-dj)

description.text: Maximal tardiness of jobs. Considers only derivations from the due date that are too late: max(0;(Cj-dj)

definition.text: Total total tardiness of jobs. Considers only derivations from the due date that are too late: max(0;(Cj-dj)

description.text: This is also a more general cost function than the total weighted completion time. Tardiness considers only derivations from the due date that are too late: max(0;w(Cj)-dj)

List of modeling approaches used for the model.
Liste der Modellierungsansätze die für das Modell genutzt wurden.
Providing versions of the simulation model and with characteristics to distinguish them.
Bereitstellung von Versionen des Simulationsmodells und mit Merkmalen zur Unterscheidung.

"Designation of the exchange format of the model. E.G.: FMI 1.0, Co-Simulation, Platform / Source - Code. FMI 2.0.2, Model Exchange, Source - Code, S-function, Version 2, 64bit, mex - Format / or C-Code, Modelica 3, encoded, VHDL

Bezeichnung des Austauschformates des Modells. Z.B.: FMI 1.0, Co-Simulation, Plattform / Source - Code FMI 2.0.2, Model Exchange, Source - Code, S-function, Version 2, 64bit, mex - Format / bzw. C-Code Modelica 3, verschlüsselt, VHDL
Provision of a version of the simulation model with information to distinguish the versions. The versions are primarily intended for bug fixes without content changes.
Bereitstellung einer Version des Simulationsmodells mit Informationen zur Unterscheidung der Versionen. Die Versionen sind in erster Linie für Fehlerbehebungen gedacht ohne inhaltliche Änderungen.
Version number of the model from the vendor.
Versionnummer des Modells vom Herstellers.
Image file to represent the model in user interfaces, e.g. in a search.
Bilddatei zur Repräsentation des Modells in Oberflächen wie z.B. in einer Suche.
Deployment of the model file.
Bereitstellung der Model-Datei.
contains information about this release
Informationen oder hinweise zu diesem Release
release notes link or file
Datei oder Verknüpfung zum Release Notes Dokument
List of modeling approaches used for the model.
Liste der Modellierungsansätze die für das Modell genutzt wurden.

Interfaces of the model. This includes inputs, outputs as well as acausal connections (e.g. mechanical connections). In addition, it is specified here whether the model provides binary interfaces (e.g. for visualization).

Schnittstellen des Modells. Dies beinhaltet sowohl Eingänge, Ausgänge als auch akausale Verbindungen (z.B. mechanische Verbindungen). Zudem wird hier angegeben, ob das Modell binäre Schnittstellen beinhaltet (z.B. für die Visualisierung).
List of ports of the model. These include a name, a description, a list of variables, and a list of ports.
Liste der Ports des Modells. Diese beinhalten einen Namen, eine Beschreibung, eine Liste an Variablen sowie eine Liste an Ports.
Name of the Connector Port.
Name des Port-Connectors.
Description of the Connector Port.
Beschreibung des Port-Connectors.
List of variables of the port.
Liste der Variablen des Ports.
Name of the variable.
Name der Variable.
Range of values for the variable (e.g. [min, max], [min, max[, ]min, max], ]min, max[, {val1, val2, ...}).
Wertebereich für die Variable (z.B. [min, max], [min, max[, ]min, max], ]min, max[, {val1, val2, ...}).
Type of the variable (e.g. Real, Integer, Boolean, String or Enum).
Typ der Variable (z.B. Real, Integer, Boolean, String oder Enum).
Description of the variable.
Beschreibung der Variable.
The most common units can be selected here. .. If "others" is selected, a free text can be entered.
Hier können die gebräuchlichsten Einheiten ausgewählt werden. .. Bei Auswahl "others" kann ein Freitext angegeben werden.
Text field for missing units of the list
Freitext für fehlende Einheiten der Liste
The causality of the variable: input to inputs, output to ouputs, acausal connections (e.g. mechanical connection) do not have causality.
Kausalität der Variable: input für Eingänge, output für Ausgänge, akausale Verbindungen (z.B. mechanische Verbindung) besitzen keine Kausalität.

Prefix for acausal variable. Potential variables are set equal when connecting (no prefix). Stream variables are connected according to Kirchhoff's law, i.e. the sum of the variables equals zero. The bi-directional flow of matter is described with "stream" (e.g. for enthalpy).

Prefix für akausale Variable. Potentialvariablen werden beim Verbinden gleich gesetzt (kein Prefix). Flussvariablen werden nach Kirchhoffs Gesetz verbunden, d.h. die Summe der Variablen entspricht Null. Der bi-direktionale Fluss von Materie wird mit "stream" beschrieben (z.B. für Enthalpie).

Binary interfaces (binaryType) based on the FMI 3.0 standard (https://fmi-standard.org/docs/3.0-dev/#definition-of-types). At this point the name (e.g. "Binary interface visualization") and the description (e.g. "Interface for binary transfer of visualization information") are specified.

Binäre Schnittstellen (binaryType) basierend auf dem FMI-3.0-Standard (https://fmi-standard.org/docs/3.0-dev/#definition-of-types). An dieser Stelle werden der Name (z.B. "Binärschnittstelle Visualisierung") und die Beschreibung (z.B. "Schnittstelle zum binären Übertragen von Visualisierungsinformationen") angegeben.
Binary interface name.
Name der binären Schnittstelle.
Binary interface description.
Beschreibung der binären Schnittstelle.
List of basic physical characteristics which are represented by the model.
Liste an grundsätzlichen pysikalischen Eigenschaften welche durch das Modell abgebildet werden.
